title: Journalism Jargon
description: Step into the newsroom and test your knowledge of the terms reporters and editors use every day.

questions.question: In journalism, what is a 'lede'?
options: The opening sentence or paragraph of a news story
The editor-in-chief
The headline of a story
A confidential source

questions.question: What does 'above the fold' mean?
options: Information that is classified
Content appearing on the top half of a newspaper's front page
A story that has been censored
The masthead of a newspaper

questions.question: What is a 'byline' in journalism?
options: A deadline for submitting stories
A secondary headline
A line crediting the author of an article
The last line of an article

questions.question: What does 'off the record' mean?
options: A story that has been retracted
An unconfirmed rumor
Information given with the understanding it will not be published or attributed
Not recorded on tape

questions.question: What is a 'slug' in newsroom terminology?
options: A typographical error
A rejected story
A short label or identifier used to track a story during production
A slow news day

questions.question: What does 'bury the lede' mean?
options: Hide a story from publication
Cancel a story at the last minute
Write a very short article
Place the most important information too far into the story rather than at the beginning

questions.question: What is an 'op-ed'?
options: An editor's correction
An operational editorial meeting
An opinion piece published opposite the editorial page
A breaking news bulletin

questions.question: What does 'dateline' refer to in a news article?
options: The publication deadline
The line at the beginning of a story indicating where and sometimes when it was filed
The date the story was written
A timeline of events in the story

questions.question: What is a 'stringer' in journalism?
options: A press photographer
Someone who strings newspaper headlines together
A copy editor
A freelance journalist who contributes to a publication without being on staff

questions.question: What does 'embargo' mean in journalism?
options: A retraction of a story
A ban on a reporter
A type of newspaper format
A restriction on publishing information until a specified date and time

questions.question: What is a 'beat' in journalism?
options: A specific subject area or geographic region a reporter regularly covers
Scooping a rival newspaper
A rhythm in writing
The pace of a news broadcast

questions.question: What does 'inverted pyramid' refer to?
options: An upside-down chart
A method of stacking newspapers
A type of news organization hierarchy
A writing structure that puts the most important information first, with details following in decreasing order of importance

questions.question: What is a 'scoop' in journalism?
options: A summary paragraph
A type of camera lens
A correction to a previous article
An exclusive story published before competitors

questions.question: What does 'masthead' refer to?
options: The ship used by a war correspondent
The first page of a newspaper
The largest headline on the page
The section of a publication listing ownership, editors, and contact information

questions.question: What is a 'sidebar' in journalism?
options: An advertisement placed next to an article
A conversation at a bar
A short, supplementary article that accompanies a main story
The margin of a newspaper page
